newsitem.title: FRANCE: EU proposes farm reforms, cereal support price cut.
newsitem.headline: EU proposes farm reforms, cereal support price cut.

text.p: The European Commission on Tuesday approved farm reform proposals, including a cut in the cereals intervention price, to prepare for EU expansion eastwards after 2000, a Commission spokesman said.
"The proposals were adopted," the spokesman said, adding they would be published on Wednesday.

A copy, obtained by Reuters, proposed a 20 percent cut in the cereals intervention price, half compensated by an increase in direct aid payments to farmers, and the compulsory set-aside reference rate would be reduced at zero, from 17.5 percent.
Under the proposal, the cereals intervention price would in 2000 be cut in one step to 95.35 ecus a tonne, from 119.19 ecus currently.

A non-crop specific area payment covering cereals, oilseeds and protein crops, such as peas and beans, would in 2000 be set at 66 ecus a tonne multiplied by regional cereals reference yields fixed under 1992 EU farm reforms.
Cereals producers currently receive a basic compensation payment of 54.35 ecus a tonne.
The reference rate for compulsory cereals, oilseed and protein crop set-aside would be set at zero and penalty set-aside abolished but voluntary set-aside allowed.
Maize and other silage cereals would be excluded from the new farm measures.
Extra aid of 13 ecus a tonne would be granted for protein crops to help preserve their competitiveness with cereals.
